candidates.title: Make 'Sites' the default webserver app

labels.name: Dev Experience
labels.description: Related to the experience of developers

candidates.body:
# Description

This PR makes the Sites app the default server for storing/serving UI artifacts, instead of requiring the same `storeSys` boilerplate to be used within every app.

Accordingly, both the package infra and psibase CLI tool were updated to call `storeSys` on `sites`.

Furthermore, I needed to add a Sites plugin to accommodate the Branding app, which was previously calling its own `storeSys` action manually.

I removed the `storageInterface`, `WebContentRow`, and `serveContent` as interfaces, since they are no longer needed.

# Docs changes

I also updated StorageInterface docs, CLI docs, and package support docs.

# Benefits

* Simpler to write services: 99% of cases it is unnecessary to add the store/serveContent boilerplate to a service.
* RPC services can now be used exclusively for servicing queries, which makes them read-only and easier to reason about
* Makes upgrades to UI storage/service easier as it is now centralized. For example it should now be fairly trivial to add gzip compression on all artifacts that use the Sites app.

candidates.title: Union cargo package dependencies

labels.name: Dev Experience
labels.description: Related to the experience of developers

candidates.body:
This allows package dependencies to be specified in any crate in a cargo-package instead of only the service crate.
Dependencies put in multiple crates will be unioned for inclusion in the final package.

This PR also moves the dependencies for the ChainMail package from the service crate to the root crate. It does not demonstrate unioning capabilities which were manually tested.

-----
Merge to `main` once #859 is merged.

candidates.title: Default deploy chainmail

labels.name: System app
labels.description: Related to system services and their apps/plugins

candidates.body:
This PR ensures that the ChainMail app is deployed to the chain by default.

To accomplish this, the [new functionality](https://github.com/gofractally/psibase/pull/840) in `cargo-psibase` that allows for UI and postinstall scripts to be specified is leveraged in chainmail.

Also, this PR introduces a new CMake function `cargo_psibase_package` that allows psibase devs to tell CMake about packages that are built using `cargo-psibase package` rather than using the CMake `psibase_package` function. Therefore cargo-psibase-managed packages can be integrated into the regular build system just like the other packages.

candidates.title: Build .psi packages with cargo-psibase

labels.name: Dev Experience
labels.description: Related to the experience of developers

candidates.body:
A crate that builds a psibase package must have the field `package.metadata.psibase.package-name` set in its `Cargo.toml` file. Test cases should use `packages` with the package names instead of `services`. Packages that are used in test cases should be in `dev-dependencies` if they are not already in `dependencies`.

Fields in `[package.metadata.psibase]`
- package-name: required to build a package
- services: a list of crates that are services. Defaults to containing only self. Crates other than self must be in dependencies. A package with no services can be built by explicitly setting this to empty.
- plugin: a crate that will be built with `cargo component` and uploaded as `/plugin.wasm`
- server: a service that will be included in the package and set as the server of this service (may be the current service)
- dependencies: A list of additional package dependencies. These packages must already exist in the package repository as they will not be built by cargo.

candidates.title: Add temporary login functionality
candidates.body:
# Login Description 

This PR adds functionality to the accounts plugin (`loginTemp` function) that allows users to "log in" to apps (if apps provide such functionality). If no user is logged in to an app, and a plugin schedules a transaction for execution, the current behavior will automatically log in "alice". This maintains the existing behavior that alice is the sender of all transactions by default, except this PR adds the ability to change the sender by calling `loginTemp` with a different account name.

Login is app-specific, meaning if an app calls `accounts:plugin/accounts->loginTemp("alice")` to log alice in, she is only logged in on that particular app. 

The final `login` function that will replace and obsolete `loginTemp` will spawn a new tab with an oauth-like login flow. But until that exists, we have this temporary function to allow apps to directly log users in.

# ClientData plugin

This PR also introduces the `ClientData` plugin, as mentioned in the plugin storage [specification](https://github.com/gofractally/psibase/issues/740).

candidates.title: Add plugin storage
candidates.body:
### Description

This adds the ability for plugins to link to the [`wasi-keyvalue` interface](https://github.com/WebAssembly/wasi-keyvalue/blob/main/wit/world.wit) to have a data storage layer.

### Storage technology

LocalStorage was used for the first implementation over IndexedDB because it is a synchronous interface. 

In the future we can migrate to use IndexedDB to increase the amount of storage available for plugins, perhaps once [JSPI](https://github.com/WebAssembly/js-promise-integration/blob/main/proposals/js-promise-integration/Overview.md) is more widely available.

### Exclusions

* Currently a known bug in the implementation of `list-keys`, so it is currently commented out and unavailable everywhere.
* The increment function is supposed to be atomic, but it is not. It currently just outputs a warning that it is non-atomic.

### Unit test output

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/ff81622d-6ec1-4928-bfab-e32f21fc6a88)

candidates.title: Identity Attestation implementation

labels.name: System app
labels.description: Related to system services and their apps/plugins

candidates.body:
This PR includes
- Identity Plugin, which accepts a subject and a identity confidence score expressed as a percentage / float. It verifies the subject is an account on chain and converts the float to an unsigned int.
- Identity Service - stores the attester, subject, and confidence score as well as storing stats on attestations so an attestation summary can be queried for any subject.
- getAccount() added to the Accounts plugin
- Attestation graph UI moved to the Identity folder

We decided *not* to separate identity and attestation into separate services as originally describe as such below:
- Identity Plugin, which provides a restricted, purpose-built "frontend" for the more general-case Attestation service
- Attestation Service, which accepts arbitrary attestations from any source and stores (and serves) them
- Attestation Plugin, which provides the frontend for the Attestation Service

Generally, this is a first-pass implementation. What will need more attention in the future follows:
- The event-related Queries will need tweaking once that subsystem is complete and stable.
- The attestation Queries api will need to be tweaked and implemented where not currently. I've opted to stop at this point, given my ability to test for non-alice accounts severely restricts the test cases, not to mention we don't have a real front-end for the Identity or Attestation service, and it's needs will become more obvious once we get back to the broader fractally implementation.

candidates.title: AuthSig improvements

labels.name: System app
labels.description: Related to system services and their apps/plugins

candidates.body:
This PR is mostly refactoring existing functionality:
1. Refactors the SPKI library that was previously coupled to AuthSig/RAuthSig, it is now its own library in the same namespace that can be independently linked
2. Minor improvement to the tester, starting to remove its dependency on the `psibase::PublicKey` type (secp256k1 keys), which is being deprecated.
3. Wraps `AuthSig` and `AuthK1` in their own namespaces, to better isolate functionality that is specific to each auth library.

And there are a few additions also related to auth:
1. Adds some functionality to the AuthSig plugin (The ability to set the key of the caller, and the ability to create and return a new keypair in pem format)
2. Adds a new library (also in AuthSig namespace) for parsing PEM to PrivateKeyInfo. Basically the private key equivalent to the SPKI library, although there's no packing/unpacking logic because it's intended to be used for signing in tests, not as objects that can packed and sent to the node.
